content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Diabetes Self-Management Training Act of 2007". Congress finds that diabetes is a major public health threat in the United States, with 21 million people currently living with diabetes and 54 million with pre-diabetes. Diabetes is the 6th leading cause of death, with the prevalence of the most common type tripling in the last 30 years. Diabetes is the 6th leading cause of death in the United States, with at least 224,000 deaths annually. The prevalence of the most common type of diabetes has tripled in the last 30 years, and approximately 2,200 people are diagnosed each day. Diabetes self-management training, also known as diabetes education, provides critical knowledge and skills to help patients effectively manage their condition. A certified diabetes educator, often a nurse, assists patients in identifying barriers, problem-solving, and developing coping skills. Diabetes self-management training, provided by certified diabetes educators, helps patients with diabetes identify barriers, facilitate problem-solving, and develop coping skills to effectively manage their condition and reduce risks and complications. Diabetes self-management training is effective in reducing risks and complications of diabetes. A study in 2002 showed that lifestyle changes can decrease the risk of developing type 2 diabetes by 58 percent. Participants at increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes reduced their risk by 58% through lifestyle changes. This intervention was particularly effective for those aged 60 and older, with a 71% reduction in diabetes development. Patients under the care of a certified diabetes educator also showed improved diabetes control and health status. Studies have shown that patients under the care of certified diabetes educators have better control of their diabetes and improved health status. Lifestyle changes taught by these educators lead to improved glycemic control and reduced complications from diabetes, with the potential for preventing serious medical complications by up to 90% (blindness), 85% (amputations), and 50% (heart disease and stroke) through proper medical treatment and self-management. Complications from diabetes can be reduced by up to 90% (blindness), 85% (amputations), and 50% (heart disease and stroke) with proper medical treatment and self-management. Over 20,000 diabetes educators in the US are certified by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators, requiring specific health care credentials for eligibility. Diabetes educators certified by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators must meet specific health care credentials, have professional practice experience in diabetes self-management training, pass a national examination, and renew their credentials periodically. Certification Board for Diabetes Educators requires passing a national examination and renewing credentials. Certified educators can provide diabetes self-management training under Medicare. Certified diabetes educators are recognized as certified providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. Certified diabetes educators are now included as providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. A diabetes educator is a licensed health care professional specializing in teaching individuals with diabetes to manage their condition. They must be certified by a recognized certifying body. A diabetes educator must be certified by a recognized certifying body, such as the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators or a body recognized by the Secretary. To be certified as a diabetes educator, the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators or a recognized certifying body must meet specific requirements set by the Secretary. To be certified as a diabetes educator, a certifying body must meet specific requirements, including having a qualifying credential in a specified health care profession and professional practice experience in diabetes self-management training. To become a certified diabetes educator, individuals must have a qualifying credential in a specified health care profession, professional practice experience in diabetes self-management training, pass a national certification examination, and renew certification periodically. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to identify barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing self-management training services, including economic and geographic obstacles, referrals, and provider availability. A report on the study's findings is due within one year. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes accessing self-management training services. A report on the study's findings is due within one year. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations for outreach methods and report on them. The Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations on effective outreach methods to educate primary care physicians and the public about the benefits of diabetes self-management training within one year of the enactment of this Act. The Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will submit a report to Congress on recommendations for diabetes self-management training within one year of the Act's enactment. The amendments for outpatient self-management training services will apply six months after the Act's enactment.
